5.text: Amen:  My name is Amen Sibtain, I'm a consultant

7.text:
clinical oncologist
and my NHS practice is at St Bartholomew's

11.text:
hospital in London.
So the term 'Bowel Cancer' normally refers

15.text:
to colon cancer or rectal cancer.
The bowel itself actually is the enitre digestive

21.text:
tract,
running from the stomach down to the anus

25.text:
where the poo comes out of
and thats split into the large bowel and the

29.text:
small bowel.
So when we talk about colon and rectum cancer,

33.text:
we're talking about large bowel cancer
and that's normally shortened to just bowel

37.text:
cancer.
The signs and symptoms are, a change in bowel

41.text:
habit that is not getting better after a few
weeks

44.text:
on standard treatments that your GP may give
you,

48.text:
bleeding from the bottom, usually mixed in
with the stool

51.text:
or if theres bleeding when one wipes oneself
with loo paper.

56.text:
It's important to qualify that bleeding from
the bowel isn't an automatic sign of bowel

61.text:
cancer,
there are a lot of other causes, but it is

63.text:
a persistent change in bowel habit that's probably
the most important.

68.text:
Other things to watch out for are abdominal
pain.

71.text:
A loss of appetite and weight loss are also
factors to look for

75.text:
Some people may be embarrassed about talking
about something that we don't normally talk

79.text:
about every day,
so it's obvious to feel some embarrassment.

83.text: But be reassured that the doctor will not  be embarrassed and is used to dealing

86.text: with this all day every day.

89.text: The first diagnostic test is a technique that

92.text:
looks at the lining of the bowel
and thats usually a flexible sigmoidoscopy.

97.text:
Then if there is something suspicious there,
they can take a biopsy there and then.

101.text:
That is a sample of any suspicious lump and
that is sent off for analysis.

107.text:
If nothing can be seen, but there is still
a high degree of suspicion

111.text:
that there may be something going on further
up the bowel, further up the colon,

117.text:
a full colonoscopy is done, which usually
requires a separate visit.

122.text:
The patients have to clear out their bowel
before attending and they're given some sedation.

128.text:
The process takes about 20 -25 minutes in
total and this is an excellent way of looking

134.text:
at the inside of the bowel,
right from the rectum, at the bottom, all

137.text:
the way round to the right hand side of the
bowel.

142.text:
So if all of the tests show the tumour is
confined to the bowel itself and has not spread

146.text:
anywhere else,
the main treatment is surgery, and the surgery

150.text:
involves removal of the relevant part of the
bowel

153.text:
along with things called 'lymph nodes'.
Nowadays if the tumour has only spread to

159.text:
the liver and there is no sign of any spread
anywhere else

163.text:
and it is seen to be technically possible
to remove part of the liver along with the

169.text:
bowel,
then that can be done and can be curative.

172.text:
If there is spread elsewhere one has to think
about what symptoms the patient is having.

177.text:
If there are major symptoms from the tumour
itself in the bowel,

181.text:
then surgery still may be done to prevent
or relieve those symptoms,

186.text:
but if the disease has spread then the main
treatment is chemotherapy.
